title: Bolzano–Weierstrass theorem
summary: In mathematics, specifically in real analysis, the Bolzano–Weierstrass theorem, named after Bernard Bolzano and Karl Weierstrass, is a fundamental result about convergence in a finite-dimensional Euclidean space R n {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}} . The theorem states that each infinite bounded sequence in R n {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}} has a convergent subsequence.[1] An equivalent formulation is that a subset of R n {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}} is sequentially compact if and only if it is closed and bounded.[2] The theorem is sometimes called the sequential compactness theorem.[3]
